Retrieved March 19, 2007. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071217093738/http://hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/media/nr-cp/2002/2002_care-soinsbk4_e.html "Canada Health Act Overview"], News Release by [[Health Canada]], November 25, 2002. Retrieved March 19, 2007. *[http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/hcs-sss/alt_formats/hpb-dgps/pdf/pubs/chaar-ralcs-0203/chaar-ralcs-0203-eng.pdf "Canada Health Act Annual Report 2002-2003 (PDF Version - 1,873KB)"], Annual Report by Health Canada, December, 2003. Retrieved January 19, 2011. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080509133951/http://www.saskndp.com/about/history/founding_people/history_tommy "A Short Introduction to Tommy Douglas and his Government 1944-1960"], by editors of the saskndp.com website, Regina, SK, Canada, 1999 - 2007. Retrieved March 19, 2007. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110706164038/http://www.ndpopposition.ab.ca/node/1578 "Timeline of NDP fight against the Third Way"]<sup>(not found) (automated/user archive disallow by robots.txt)</sup>, by editors of the ndpopposition.ab.ca website, Edmonton, AB, Canada, April 20, 2006. Retrieved March 19, 2007. Dead link tagged June 28, 2016. *[http://www.health.alberta.ca/AHCIP/what-is-covered.html "Health Care Insurance" "What is Covered Under the AHCIP" "Basic services covered in Alberta"] by editors of the Alberta Health website, Edmonton, AB, Canada, 1995-2016. Retrieved June 29, 2016. * note: Alberta Hospitalization (insurance) Plan(s) is not a notable or trending search result in social media or an inactive political agenda online

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2) ([[User:Balon Greyjoy|Balon Greyjoy]])
/* top */Journal cites, Added 1 doi to a journal cite
revision.text:
'''Intelligence and personality''' have some common features; for example, they both follow a relatively stable pattern throughout the whole of an individual’s life, which is genetically determined in different degrees.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Caspi |first=A. |title=The child is father of the man: personality continuities from childhood to adulthood |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=78 |issue=1 |date=2000|pages=158–172 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.78.1.158}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Deary |first1= I. J. |last2=Whalley |first2= L. J.|last3=Lemmon |first3= H. |last4=Crawford |first4= J. R. |last5= Starr |first5= J. M. |date=2000 |title=The stability of individual differences in mental ability from childhood to old age: follow-up of the 1932 Scottish Mental Survey|journal=Intelligence |volume=28|issue=1|pages=49–55 |doi=10.1016/s0160-2896(99)00031-8}}</ref> In addition, they are both significant predictors of various outcomes, such as educational achievement, occupational performance, and health.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Barrick |first1=M. R. |last2= Mount |first2= M. K. |date= 1991 |title= The Big Five personality dimensions and job performance: A meta - analysis |journal= Personnel Psychology |volume=44 |pages=1–26 |doi=10.1111/j.1744-6570.1991.tb00688.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Calvin |first1= C. |last2= Batty|first2=G. D. |last3=Deary |first3=I. J. |date= 2011|title= Cognitive epidemiology: Concepts, evidence, and future directions. |publisher=Oxford:Wiley–Blackwell}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kern|first1=M.|last2=Friedman,|first2=H.|date=2011|title=Personality and health|publisher=Oxford:Wiley–Blackwell}}</ref><ref name=" Poropat2009">{{cite journal|last1=Poropat |first1= A. |date=2009|title=A meta-analysis of the five-factor model of personality and academic performance|journal=Psychological Bulletin |volume=135|pages=322–338 |doi=10.1037/a0014996}}</ref> However, the traditional view in psychology is that there is no meaningful relationship between personality and intelligence and they should be studied as separate entities.
Firstly, intelligence is considered to be a cognitive process, while personality is recognised as being non-cognitive, and this implies that there is a great distinction between personality and intelligence. However, other psychologists argue that the distinction between cognitive and non-cognitive is vague because almost all personality traits have cognitive attributes, although they are more obvious in some traits than in others. For example, neuroticism is a personality trait, but is also related to rumination and compulsive thinking about possible threats,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nolan|first1=S. A. |last2= Roberts|first2= J. E.|last3= Gotlib|first3= I. H.|date= 1998|title= Neuroticism and ruminative response style as predictors of change in depressive symptomatology|journal=Cognitive Therapy and Research|volume=22|pages=445–455|doi=10.1023/a:1018769531641}}</ref> while agreeableness is associated with understanding and considering the mental state of others.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nettle|first1= D. |last2= Liddle |first2=B.|date=2008 |title=Agreeableness is related to social-cognitive, but not social-perceptual, theory of mind|journal=European Journal of Personality |volume= 22|pages= 323–335 |doi=10.1002/per.672}}</ref>
In addition, different methods are generally used to assess intelligence and personality. Intelligence is normally measured by means of ability tests, whereas personality is usually assessed by means of questionnaires. Furthermore, different typical measurements lead to another conceptual distinction, which is that intelligence is considered to indicate individuals’ ''maximal performance'', while personality is believed to reflect their ''typical behaviour''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cronbach|first1= L. J. |date= 1949|title=Essentials of psychological testing }}</ref> However, others argue that multiple methods can be used to assess intelligence and personality; for example, questionnaires that require to be rated by self, peers or observers can also be used to measure individuals’ mental ability, although these kinds of measurement may lack accuracy. Therefore, different typical methods cannot prove that the relationship between intelligence and personality is a meaningless one. In addition, since individuals’ ability can also affect their typical behaviour, IQ can predict outcomes related to aspects such as performance at work, academic achievement, and health.<ref>{{cite book|last1= Sternberg |first1=R. J.|last2= Grigorenko |first2= E. L.| title=The general factor of intelligence: How general is it? |pages= 331–380|location=Mahwah |publisher= NJ: Erlbaum}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gottfredson |first1=L. S. |last2=Deary|first2= I. J. |date= 2004|title=Intelligence predicts health and longevity, but why?|journal= Current Directions in Psychological Science|volume=13|pages=1–4 |doi=10.1111/j.0963-7214.2004.01301001.x}}</ref> Therefore, ability tests can provide indices of both maximal performance and typical behaviour.
An increasing number of studies have recently explored the relationship between intelligence and the Big Five personality traits.
==Openness/Intellect== [[Openness to experience|Openness]] shows the strongest positive relationship with ''g'' among the Big Five personality traits, ranging from r=.06 to r=.42.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= Ashton |first1=M. C. |last2= Lee. |first2= K.|last3=Vernon|first3=P. A.|last4=Jang|first4=K. L. |date= 2000 |title=Fluid intelligence, crystallized intelligence, and the Openness/Intellect factor.|journal=Journal of Research in Personality |volume=34|pages=197–207 |doi=10.1006/jrpe.1999.2276}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Austin|first1=E. J.|last2= Deary|first2= I. J.|last3=Gibson|first3=G. J. |date= 1997|title= Relationship between ability and personality: Three hypotheses tested. |journal=Intelligence|volume=25 |pages= 49–70 |doi=10.1016/s0160-2896(97)90007-6}}</ref><ref name="Austin2002">{{cite journal|last1=Austin= |first1=A. J.|last2= Deary |first2= I. J. |last3=Whiteman|first3= M. C. |last4=Fowkes|first4=F. G. R. |last5= Padersen|first5=N. L. |last6= Rabbitt, |first6=P.|last7=Bent |first7= N. |last8= McInnes |first8=L. |date= 2002|title= Relationships between ability and personality: Does intelligence contribute positively to personal and social adjustment? |journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=32|pages=1391–1411 |doi=10.1016/s0191-8869(01)00129-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Chamorro-Premuzic|first1= T. |last2=Furnham|first2=A. |date= 2008|title=Personality, intelligence and approaches to learning as predictors of academic performance.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=44 |pages=1596–1603 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2008.01.003}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= DeYoung|first1= C. G.|last2=Peterson|first2= J. B.|last3= Higgins|first3= D.M.|date= 2005 |title= Sources of Openness/Intellect: Cognitive and neuropsychological correlates of the fifth factor of personality. |journal=Journal of Personality|volume=73|pages= 825–858|doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.2005.00330.x|pmid=15958136}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Furnham|first1=A.|last2=Chamorro-Premuzic|first2=T.|date=2004|title=Personality, intelligence, and art.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=36|pages=705–715|doi=10.1016/s0191-8869(03)00128-4}}</ref> Individuals with a high level of openness enjoy the experience of learning and prefer an intellectually stimulating environment. Therefore, openness shows a significant moderate association with [[Fluid and crystallized intelligence|crystallized intelligence]] (r=.30), but a non-significant low association with [[Fluid and crystallized intelligence|fluid intelligence]] (r=.08),<ref name="Ackerman1997">{{cite journal|last1= Ackerman|first1=P. L. |last2= Heggestad|first2=E. D.|date= 1997|title= Intelligence, personality, and interests: Evidence for overlapping traits. |journal= Psychological Bulletin|volume=121|pages=219–245|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.121.2.219}}</ref> and these results are consistent with those of other studies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bates|first1=T. C.|last2=Shieles|first2=A.|date=2003 |title= Crystallized intelligence as a product of speed and drive for experience: The relationship of inspection time and openness to g and Gc. |journal=Intelligence |volume= 31|pages=275–287 |doi=10.1016/s0160-2896(02)00176-9}}</ref>
Some psychologists have recently pointed out that previous instruments used to measure openness actually assessed two distinctive aspects. The first is intellect, which reflects intellectual engagement and perceived intelligence and is marked by ideas, while the second is emotion, which reflects the artistic and contemplative qualities related to being engaged in sensation and perception and is marked by fantasy, aesthetics, feelings and actions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= DeYoung|first1=C. G.|last2=Quilty |first2=L. C. |last3=Peterson|first3= J. B.|date=2007|title=Between facets and domains: 10 aspects of the Big Five. |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=93|pages= 880–896 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.93.5.880 |pmid=17983306}}</ref> On this basis, intellect was found to be associated with the neural system of the working memory, which is related to ''g'', whereas openness was not.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=DeYoung|first1= C. G. |last2= Shamosh|first2= N. A.|last3=Green|first3=A. E.|last4= Braver|first4= T. S.|last5=Gray|first5=J. R.|date= 2009 |title=Intellect as distinct from Openness: Differences revealed by fMRI of working memory. |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume= 97|pages=883–892 |doi=10.1037/a0016615 |pmid=19857008 |pmc=2805551}}</ref> In addition, according to a study of genetic behaviour, intellect is genetically closer to intelligence than openness.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wainwright|first1=M. A. |last2= Wright |first2= M. J. |last3=Luciano |first3=M.|last4=Geffen|first4=G. M. |last5= Martin |first5= N. G. |date= 2008|title= Genetic covariation among facets of openness to experience and general cognitive ability .|journal= Twin Research and Human Genetics|volume=11 |pages=275–286 |doi=10.1375/twin.11.3.275}}</ref>
==Conscientiousness== The association between [[conscientiousness]] and intelligence is complex and uncertain. Individuals with a lower level of intelligence are always assumed to tend to behave in an orderly fashion and do extra work, which is related to being conscientious, in order to compensate for their lower level of cognitive ability.<ref name="Chamorro-Premuzic2005">{{cite journal|last1= Chamorro-Premuzic|first1=T.|last2=Moutafi|first2=J.|last3=Furnham|first3=A.|date= 2005|title=The relationship between personality traits, subjectively-assessed and fluid intelligence.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=38|issue=7 |pages=1517–1528|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2004.09.018}}</ref> However, although intelligence has been observed to be negatively correlated with conscientiousness in some studies,<ref name=" Poropat2009"/><ref name="Chamorro-Premuzic2005"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moutafi|first1=J.|last2=Furnham|first2=A.|last3=Crump|first3=J.|date= 2003|title=Demographic and personality predictors of intelligence: A study using the NEO Personality Inventory and the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. |journal=European Journal of Personality|volume=17|pages=79–94|doi=10.1002/per.471}}</ref><ref name="Judge2007">{{cite journal|last1= Judge|first1=T. A.|last2=Jackson|first2=C. L.|last3=Shaw|first3= J. C.|last4=Scott |first4=B. A.|last5=Rich|first5=B. L. |date=2007 |title=Self-efficacy and work-related performance: the integral role of individual differences |journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|volume=92|issue=1 |pages=107–127 |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.92.1.107 |pmid=17227155}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Moutafi|first1=J.|last2=Furnham|first2=A.|last3=Crump|first3=J.|date= 2006|title= What facets of openness and conscientiousness predict fluid intelligence score? |journal=Learning and Individual Differences|volume=16 |pages=31–42|doi=10.1016/j.lindif.2005.06.003}}</ref> others have not found this correlation to be significant and have even found a positive relationship.<ref name="Austin2002"/><ref name="Ackerman1997"/>
Furthermore, some interaction has been found between conscientiousness and intelligence. Conscientiousness has been found to be a stronger predictor of safety behaviour in individuals with a low level of intelligence than in those with a high level.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Postlethwaite|first1= B.|last2= Robbins|first2=S.|last3= Rickerson|first3= J.|last4=McKinniss|first4= T.|date=2009|title= The moderation of conscientiousness by cognitive ability when predicting workplace safety behaviour.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume= 47 |pages= 711–716|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2009.06.008}}</ref> This interaction may also be found in educational and occupational settings in future studies. Therefore, relatively speaking, an increase in either conscientiousness or intelligence may compensate for a deficiency in the other.
==Extraversion== The results of a meta-analysis research conducted in 1997, which consisted of 35 studies, indicated that there is a very small, but statistically significant positive correlation between [[Extraversion and introversion|Extraversion]] and ''g'' (r=.08).<ref name="Ackerman1997"/> Another recent meta-analysis of extraversion, which comprised 50 new studies, reported a similar correlation (r=.05).<ref name="Wolf2005">{{cite journal|last1=Wolf|first1= M. B. |last2=Ackerman|first2=P. L.|date= 2005|title=Extraversion and intelligence: A meta-analytic investigation. |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=39 |pages=531–542 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2005.02.020}}</ref>
There are some moderating variables in the relationship between extraversion and ''g'' including differences in the assessment instruments and samples’ age and sensory stimulation; for example, no meaningful correlation was found between extraversion and intelligence in the samples of children.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rawlings |first1=D. |last2=Skok|first2=M.|date=1993|title= Extraversion, venturesomeness and intelligence in children.|journal= Personality and Individual Differences|volume=15|pages=389–396|doi=10.1016/0191-8869(93)90066-c}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Saklofske|first1=D. H.|last2= Kostura|first2= D. D.|date=1990|title= Extraversion–introversion and intelligence.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=11 |pages=547–551|doi=10.1016/0191-8869(90)90036-q}}</ref> Furthermore, Bates and Rock (2004) used [[Raven's Progressive Matrices|Raven’s matrices]] and found that extraverts performed better than introverts with increasing auditory stimulation,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bates|first1=T. C.|last2=Rock|first2=A.|date=2004|title=Personality and information processing speed: Independent influences on intelligent performance. |journal=Intelligence|volume=32|issue=1|pages=33–46|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2003.08.002}}</ref> whereas introverts performed best in silence. This result is consistent with that of Revelle et al. (1976).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Revelle|first1=W.|last2=Amaral|first2=P.|last3=Turriff |first3=S. |date= 1976|title= Introversion/extraversion, time stress, and caffeine|journal=Science |volume= 192 |pages= 149–150 |doi=10.1126/science.1257762}}</ref> In addition, different measures and different sub-traits of extraversion have been found to cause significantly different correlations.<ref name="Wolf2005"/>
==Neuroticism== [[Neuroticism]] has been found to have a reliable negative association with ''g''(r=-.33).<ref name="Ackerman1997"/> However, other researchers have recently reported a lower coefficient of .09 for general mental ability and emotional stability.<ref name="Judge2007"/> Although these studies have some differences, they all indicate that intelligence increases with a decrease in negative emotion.
One of the reasons for this negative correlation is [[Test anxiety]], which refers to the psychological distress experienced by individuals prior to, or during, an evaluative situation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zuckerman |first1=M. |last2=Spielberger |first2= C. D. |title=Emotions and anxiety: New concepts, methods, and applications |pages=57–81|publisher=New York:Wiley}}</ref> This is closely associated with neuroticism <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chamorro - Premuzic|first1=T.|last2=Ahmetoglu|first2= G.|last3= Furnham |first3= A. |date= 2008|title= Little more than personality:Trait determinants of test anxiety . |journal=Learning and Individual Differences |volume=18 |pages= 258–263 |doi=10.1016/j.lindif.2007.09.002}}</ref> and has a negative influence on individuals’performance in an intelligence test (r=-.23).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wicherts|first1=J. M.|last2=Scholten|first2=A.|date=2010|title=Test anxiety and the validity of cognitive tests: A confirmatory factor analysis perspective and some empirical findings.|journal=Intelligence|volume=38 |pages=169–178|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2009.09.008}}</ref>
Some argue that all the aforementioned evidence indicates that neuroticism is related to test performance rather than true intelligence. However, according to the results of a longitudinal study recently conducted by Gow et al., (2005), neuroticism influences an age-related decline in intelligence and there is a small negative correlation between neuroticism and a change in the level of IQ (r=-.18).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gow|first1=A. J.|last2=Whiteman|first2= M. C.|last3=Pattie|first3= A.|last4= Deary |first4=I. J. |date=2005|title= The personality–intelligence interface: Insights from an ageing cohort. |journal= Personality and Individual Differences|volume=39|pages=751–761 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2005.01.028}}</ref> Although it is still debatable if neuroticism reduces general intelligence, this study provided some valuable evidence and a direction for research. In addition, some interaction between intelligence and neuroticism has been found. Individuals with a high level of neuroticism demonstrated a poor performance, health, and adjustment only if they had a low level of intelligence.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leikas|first1=S.|last2=M¨akinen|first2=S.|last3=L¨ onnqvist|first3=J.E.|last4=Verkasalo|first4= M. |date=2009|title=Cognitive ability×Emotional stability interactions on adjustment.|journal=European Journal of Personality|volume=23|pages=329–342|doi=10.1002/per.711}}</ref> Therefore, intelligence may act as a buffer and compensate neuroticism in individuals.
==Agreeableness== No significant association between agreeableness and ''g'' has been found in previous research.<ref name="Ackerman1997"/><ref name="Judge2007"/> However, some components of agreeableness have been found to be related to intelligence. For example, aggression is negatively associated with intelligence (r is around -.20) <ref name="Ackerman1997"/><ref>{{cite journal|issue=|last1=DeYoung|first1=C. G.|last2=Peterson|first2= J. B.|last3=S´eguin, |first3= J. R.|last4=Pihl|first4=R. O.|last5=Tremblay|first5= R. E.|date= 2008|title=Externalizing behavior and the higher-order factors of the Big Five. |journal= Journal of Abnormal Psychology|volume= 117|pages=947–953|doi=10.1037/a0013742|pmid=19025240}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Séguin|first1=J. R.|last2=Boulerice|first2= B.|last3= Harden|first3=P. |last4= Tremblay|first4=R. E.|last5=Pihl|first5=R. O.|date= 1999 |title=Executive functions and physical aggression after controlling for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, general memory, and IQ. |journal= Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry|volume= 40|pages= 1197–1208 |doi=10.1111/1469-7610.00536}}</ref> because unintelligent people may experience more frustration, which may lead to aggression <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lynam|first1=D. R.|last2=Moffitt|first2=T. E. |last3= Stouthamer-Loeber|first3=M. |date= 1993|title= Explaining the relation between IQ and delinquency: Class, race, test motivation, school failure, or self-control? |journal= Journal of Abnormal Psychology|volume= 102|pages=187–196 |doi=10.1037/0021-843x.102.2.187}}</ref> and aggression and intelligence may share some biological factors.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=DeYoung|first1= C. G.|last2=Peterson|first2=J. B.|last3=Séguin|first3=J. R. |last4=Mejia|first4= J. M.|last5=Pihl|first5=R. O.|last6=Beitchman|first6=J. H.|last7=Jain|first7=U. |last8=Tremblay|first8=R. E.|last9=Kennedy|first9=J. L.|last10=Palmour|first10=R. M.|date=2006|title= The dopamine D4 receptor gene and moderation of the association between externalizing behavior and IQ.|journal=Archives of General Psychiatry|volume=63|pages=1410–1416|doi=10.1001/archpsyc.63.12.1410|pmid=17146015|pmc=3283582}}</ref> In addition, emotional perception and emotional facilitation, which are also components of agreeableness, have been found to be significantly correlated with intelligence.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= Mayer|first1=J. D.|last2=Salovey|first2= P.|last3= Caruso|first3= D. R. |date= 2004|title=Emotional intelligence: Theory, findings, and implications|journal=Psychological Inquiry |volume= 60 |pages=197–215 |doi=10.1207/s15327965pli1503_02}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Mayer|first1=J. D.|last2=Salovey |first2= P. |last3= Caruso |first3=D. R. |date= 2008|title= Emotional intelligence: New ability or eclectic traits? |journal=American Psychologist|volume=63|pages= 503–517 |doi=10.1037/0003-066x.63.6.503}}</ref> This may be because emotional perception and emotional facilitation are components of emotional intelligence and some researchers have found that emotional intelligence is a Second-Stratum Factor of ''g''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=MacCann|first1=C.|last2=Joseph|first2=D. L.|last3=Newman|first3= D. A.|last4=Roberts|first4=R. D.|date=2014|title= Emotional intelligence is a second-stratum factor of intelligence: Evidence from hierarchical and bifactor models.|journal=Emotion|volume=14|issue= 2|pages= 358–374|doi=10.1037/a0034755}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Intelligence]] [[Category:Personality]] [[Category:Psychometrics]]

revision.text:
[[File:Jon Tvedt.JPG|thumb|250px|right|Jon Tvedt during a mountain run.]]
'''Jon Tvedt''' (29 June 1966 – 11 January 2009) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[orienteering]] [[Competition|competitor]] and athlete who specialized in [[mountain running]]. He died while still active in his sport.
==Career==
===Orienteering=== Tvedt originally competed in [[orienteering]]. At the 1993 World Orienteering Championships in [[West Point]], Tvedt competed in three events. He finished fourth in the short distance, jointly with [[Steven Hale]], and eleventh in the classic distance. In the [[Relay race|relay]] he finished sixth together with teammates [[Rolf Vestre]], [[Håvard Tveite]] and [[Petter Thoresen (orienteering)|Petter Thoresen]]. At the 1995 World Orienteering Championships in [[Detmold]], Tvedt finished eleventh in the short distance, sixth in the classic distance and fourth in the [[Relay race|relay]] together with teammates Petter Thoresen, [[Håvard Tveite]] and [[Bjørnar Valstad]]. Finally, at the 1999 [[World Orienteering Championships]] in [[Inverness]], Tvedt finished eighth in the classic distance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://old.orientering.no/resultater/vmres.asp#17 |title=World Orienteering Championship, senior statistics 1966–2006 |publisher=[[Norges Orienteringsforbund]] |accessdate=11 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whDf0IWo?url=http://old.orientering.no/resultater/vmres.asp |archivedate=22 February 2011 |df= }}</ref> His best placement in the [[Orienteering World Cup]] was a fourteenth place overall, achieved in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://runners.worldofo.com/jontvedt.html|title=Profile: Jon Tvedt|publisher=World of O|accessdate=11 January 2009}}</ref>
===Athletics=== Tvedt later took up [[mountain running]]. He competed internationally at the European Championships in 2005 and 2007. In 2005 he finished twentieth in the individual race, and thirteenth in the team competition. In 2007 he finished twenty-eighth in the individual race, and tenth in the team competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/internasjonalt/Documents/mt.htm |title=Norwegian international athletes – last name T |publisher=[[Norwegian Athletics Association]] |accessdate=10 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111211130550/http://friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/internasjonalt/Documents/mt.htm |archivedate=11 December 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In 1994 Tvedt won a bronze medal at the Norwegian championship in 12 kilometres cross-country running.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/nm/Documents/m12kmt.htm|title=Norwegian championships, men's 12 km cross-country running|publisher=Norwegian Athletics Association|accessdate=21 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215152746/http://friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/nm/Documents/m12kmt.htm|archivedate=15 December 2011|df=}}</ref> In 1998 Tvedt won a silver medal at the Norwegian championship in 10 kilometres cross-country running, behind [[Karl Johan Rasmussen]]. He represented the club [[FIK BFG Fana]]. In 1999 he had changed club to [[IL Gular]], and won a [[bronze medal]] at the national championship, in a race won by [[Abderrahim Goumri]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/nm/Documents/m10kmt.htm|title=Norwegian championships, men's 10 km cross-country running|publisher=Norwegian Athletics Association|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> He won the inaugural Norwegian mountain running championships in 2005, ahead of [[Odd-Bjørn Hjelmeset]] and [[Hans Martin Gjedrem]] of winter sports fame. Tvedt then defended his title three times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/nm/Documents/mmountain.htm|title=Norwegian championships, men's mountain running|publisher=Norwegian Athletics Association|accessdate=10 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509031432/http://www.friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/nm/Documents/mmountain.htm|archivedate=9 May 2012|df=}}</ref>
==Death== Tvedt died in January 2009, during a training hike at [[Gullfjellet]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Olsen|first=Bjørn Thomas|author2=Uhlving, Henrik Hylland|title=Jon Tvedt er død|url=http://www.ba.no/nyheter/article4042621.ece|work=Bergensavisen|date=11 January 2009|accessdate=11 January 2009|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tvedt, Jon}} [[Category:Norwegian orienteers]] [[Category:Male orienteers]] [[Category:Norwegian male long-distance runners]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Bergen]] [[Category:Mountaineering deaths]] [[Category:Sport deaths in Norway]] [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox lake | name = Lake Varaždin
''Varaždinsko jezero'' | image = | caption = | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Međimurje County]], [[Croatia]]
[[Varaždin County]], Croatia | coords = {{Coord|46|19|N|16|24|E|region:HR_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = [[reservoir]] | inflow = [[Drava]] | outflow = Drava | catchment = | basin_countries = Croatia | length = {{convert|7.5|km|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|1.6|km|abbr=on}} | area = {{convert|10.1|km²|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = {{convert|158|m|abbr=on}} | islands = | sections = | cities = [[Gornji Kuršanec]], [[Varaždin]], [[Bartolovec]], [[Štefanec, Varaždin County|Štefanec]] | frozen = | reference = }} '''Lake Varaždin''' ({{lang-hr|Varaždinsko jezero}}) is a [[reservoir]] on the [[Drava]] in northern [[Croatia]]. It is administratively divided between [[Međimurje County]] and [[Varaždin County]], bordered by the municipalities of [[Varaždin]], [[Trnovec Bartolovečki]] and [[Čakovec]].{{cite web | url = http://www.dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2009/PDF/01-bind.pdf | title = Geographical and meteorological data | publisher = [[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]] | work = Statistical Yearbook | year = 2009 | accessdate = 2011-09-20}} The Drava flows into the reservoir near the city of Varaždin, while the [[dam]] is located near the village of [[Šemovec]]. Lake Varaždin is one of three reservoirs built on the Drava in Croatia, the other two being the smaller [[Lake Ormož]] (which is located on the border with [[Slovenia]]) and the bigger [[Lake Dubrava]]. The three reservoirs and the [[power plant]]s they serve form the Hydro North group of hydro power plants run by the [[Hrvatska elektroprivreda|HEP Group]]. It serves the [[Čakovec Hydroelectric Power Plant|Čakovec Hydro Power Plant]], since the [[Varaždin Hydroelectric Power Plant|Varaždin Hydro Power Plant]] is served by Lake Ormož. The power plant was built in 1982.[http://www.hep.hr/proizvodnja/en/basicdata/hydro/north/default.aspx Hydro North group of hydro power plants], [[HEP Group]] ==Tourism== Lake Varaždin is also a popular [[angling]], [[leisure]] and [[water sports]] destination for many people from the region, especially during the summer. There are many [[log cabin]]s built on the shores of the lake near Varaždin and [[Gornji Kuršanec]]. ==References== {{Hydrography of Croatia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lake Varazdin}} [[Category:Lakes of Croatia|Varazdin]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Croatia|Varazdin]] [[Category:Landforms of Međimurje County]] [[Category:Landforms of Varaždin County]] {{CentralCroatia-geo-stub}}

revision.comment: Bot: removing [[User:FrescoBot/Misplaced invisible LTR marks|misplaced invisible LTR marks]] and minor changes
revision.text:
'''Licentiate of the [[Medical Council of Canada]]''', commonly abbreviated as '''LMCC''', is not a license to practice medicine, but is generally a requirement to gain an [[medical license|independent practise license]] (a license to practise [[medicine]]) in [[Canada]].
== LMCC ==
The LMCC is granted to a [[physician]] that meet the following criteria:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mcc.ca/about/mcc-and-route-to-licensure/ |title=The MCC and the route to licensure |publisher=[[Medical Council of Canada]] |accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref> * They have passed the Medical Council of Canada Qualifying Examination (MCCQE) Part I and Part II (or an acceptable clinical assessment deemed comparable to the MCCQE Part II such as the new Certification Examination in Family Medicine) * They have satisfactorily completed at least 12 months of acceptable postgraduate training or an acceptable equivalent
== Canadian Medical Register ==
A medical graduate can be registered in the Canadian Medical Register provided he or she has successfully completed:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mcc.ca/about/lmcc/ |title=Licentiate of the Medical Council of Canada (LMCC) |publisher=[[Medical Council of Canada]] |accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref> * the Qualifying Examination prior to Jan. 1, 1992, and upon submitting evidence in the form determined by the Executive Director that the candidate has satisfactorily completed at least twelve months of acceptable postgraduate training or an acceptable equivalent; or * the MCCQE Part I and the MCCQE Part II.
== License to Practice ==
The issuance of a license to practice is the function of the medical regulatory authorities. When a candidate has satisfied the various requirements imposed by the medical regulatory authority, the final step towards licensure to practice is to submit an application to the Registrar of that medical regulatory authority.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.mcc.ca/en/ Medical Council of Canada] - Official web site *[http://www.aipso.ca/licensure/LMCC.html Description of LMCC] - Association of International Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario
[[Category:Health law in Canada]] [[Category:Medical credentials]]

revision.comment: sp.: [[World Health Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{about|the commercial product|the liquid form of the element oxygen|liquid oxygen}}
'''Liquid oxygen supplements''' are products that claim to add extra oxygen to the human body, most often through a chemical process in the digestive system, like the breakdown of [[hydrogen peroxide]] or [[magnesium peroxide]]. While the FDA describes these products as being inert, and has penalized some producers who made explicit medical claims, it has not prohibited their sale.
==Liquid Oxygen== Liquid Oxygen is the name of a product that is a solution of [[hydrogen peroxide]]<ref name=NS>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19926642.000|title=Feedback|work=New Scientist|date=9 July 2008}}</ref> and other compounds including [[sodium chloride]] (common salt)<ref name="easy">[[EasyJet]] Inflight Duty Free Catalogue March 2009</ref><ref name=ABC>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/backgroundbriefing/stories/2006/1760590.htm |title=Background Briefing - 15 October 2006 - Alternative money spinners |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2006-10-15 |accessdate=2011-09-26}}</ref> that claims to help with "[[jet lag]], [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[altitude sickness]], [[headaches]], [[hangovers]], youthful skin, energy, and [[insomnia]]".<ref name="easy" /><ref>{{cite news|author=Denis Campbell |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/sep/18/health.healthandwellbeing |title=Water? It's a tonic at £40 a bottle | UK news | The Observer |publisher=Guardian |date= 2005-09-18|accessdate=2011-09-26 |location=London}}</ref>
Professor [[Ken Harvey (professor)|Ken Harvey]], a member of the [[World Health Organization]] team that formulated criteria for the promotion of medicinal drugs and a member of [[Auspharm Consumer Health Watch]], states that the product is "no more than salty water", and that most forms of water carry some dissolved oxygen.<ref name="ABC" /> The [[Federal Trade Commission]] has prosecuted some makers of such products for making "blatantly false and unsubstantiated health claims",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quackwatch.org/04ConsumerEducation/News/vitamino.html |title=FTC Attacks "Stabilized Oxygen" Claims |publisher=Quackwatch.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-26}}</ref> although it has not banned the sale of such products.
The product claims to have an effect through increasing the amount of oxygen in the body but this is unnecessary as oxygen is absorbed by the [[lungs]] via [[breathing]].<ref name="ABC" /> Among the ingredients sometimes listed by makers are [[magnesium peroxide]], or "[[deionized water]] and sodium chloride [salt]". It cannot contain simple liquid oxygen, which would boil at -297°F(-183°C) at normal pressure, but ostensibly contains oxygen in some other form, like [[hydrogen peroxide]], that will be released after consumption.<ref>[http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-452-vitamin%20o.aspx?activeingredientid=452&activeingredientname=vitamin%20o Vitamin O on WebMD]</ref>
==Vitamin O== Vitamin O is a [[dietary supplement]] marketed and sold by Rose Creek Health Products and its sister company The Staff of Life ([[doing business as]] R-Garden) since 1998.{{cn|date=September 2015}} Despite its name, the product is not recognized by nutritional science as a [[vitamin]]. In 1999, the [[Federal Trade Commission]] fined the manufacturer for making false statements claiming health benefits resulting from the use of the product. The manufacturer had claimed that taking the supplement had beneficial effects on a wide variety of ailments, including [[Angina pectoris|angina]], [[anaemia]], and various forms of [[cancer]], and that it also increased vigor and provided for a more positive state of mind. The company states that Vitamin O is "a special supplemented oxygen taken in liquid form and produced through electrical-activation with a saline solution from the ocean,"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thewolfeclinic.com/vitamino.html | title=Therapeutic Vitamin O | work=The Wolfe Clinic Website | date=26 July 2002 | accessdate=29 January 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070214003826/http://www.thewolfeclinic.com/vitamino.html | archivedate=14 February 2007}}</ref> and that the substance increases the amount of oxygen present in the blood.
While Rose Creek Health Products complied with the [[Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994]] in that the product was sold without approval by the [[Food and Drug Administration]] because no claims about its medical efficacy were made by its producers, Rose Creek collected statements from users who attributed wide-ranging benefits to taking their supplement. However, subsequent ads also ran statements allegedly coming from experts and which provided [[anecdotal evidence]] from small-scale [[clinical trial]]s showing positive results in several patients. Because of this, the [[Federal Trade Commission]] filed an injunction in March 1999 against Rose Creek Health Products Inc., stating that the ads being run in both print and online sources, including ''[[USA Today]]'', were "blatantly false".<ref name="ref2">[http://www.cnn.com/FOOD/news/9903/16/vitamin.o/ FTC files complaint against 'Vitamin O' makers], ''CNN'', published March 16, 1999. Accessed January 3, 2006.</ref> Studies run on Vitamin O showed it to be composed largely of [[Brine|salt water]] as well as a small quantity of [[germanium]], which would provide no benefits not attributable to the [[placebo effect]].<ref>{{Citation | author=Hall, Harriet A. | authorlink=Harriet A. Hall | journal=[[Scientific Review of Alternative Medicine]] | title=Analysis of Claims and of an Experiment to Prove That Oxygen is Present in "Vitamin O" | date=Spring–Summer 2003 | volume=7 | issue=1 | pages=29–33 }}</ref>
On April 28, 2000, Rose Creek Health Products Inc., agreed to pay a cash settlement of [[USD|$]]375,000 for consumer redress, and to abstain from making claims as to the health benefits attributed to the supplement, or promoting its efficacy in treating illnesses.<ref name="ref3">[http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2000/05/rosecreek2.htm Marketers of "Vitamin O" Settles FTC Charges of Making False Health Claims; Will Pay $375,000 for Consumer Redress], [[Federal Trade Commission]], accessed January 3, 2006</ref> However, in 2005, the Food and Drug Administration issued a warning letter to R-Garden, indicating that its product labeling, website, and literature that the company distributed with shipped product were promoting Vitamin O as drugs — i.e., agents intended for use in the cure, mitigation, treatment or prevention of disease.<ref name="FDA2005">{{cite web|last1=Breen|first1=Charles M|title=Inspections, Compliance, Enforcement, and Criminal Investigations. R-Garden, Inc. 08-Feb-05|url=http://www.fda.gov/ICECI/EnforcementActions/WarningLetters/2005/ucm075278.htm|publisher=[[Food and Drug Administration]]|accessdate=25 April 2016|date=8 February 2005}}</ref> These included testimonial claims that a person unable to walk because of [[congestive heart failure]] had been able to walk again and ceased taking "heart pills or pain pills" after a three-month course of the product, and that another was able to breathe very easily again despite [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] and repeated prior bouts of chronic [[bronchitis]] and [[pneumonia]] thanks to the product.<ref name="FDA2005"/> As of 2010, the product contains a disclaimer stating "This product is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure or prevent any disease".
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Dietary supplements|Related articles]] [[Category:Fraud in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=October 2010}} {{notability|Academics|date=November 2010}} }}
'''Madhu Reddy''' is a Professor in the School of Communication at [[Northwestern University]]. Previously he was a faculty member in the [[Penn State College of Information Sciences and Technology]], and the School of [[Management]] and [[Information Systems]] at the [[Missouri University of Science and Technology|University of Missouri-Rolla]].
He is the recipient of the 2002 [[Diana E. Forsythe#Diana Forsythe Prize|Diana Forsythe Prize]] given by the [http://www.amia.org/ American Medical Informatics Association] for the best paper of the year at the intersection of [[medical informatics]] and [[social science]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Diane Forsythe Award |url=http://www.amia.org/mbrcenter/wg/poi/award.asp |accessdate=2007-10-20 }}</ref> Reddy currently chairs the Diana Forsythe Award Committee.
==Education== Dr. Reddy received his [[Ph.D.]] in [[Information Science|Information]] and [[Computer Science]] from the [[University of California, Irvine]] in 2005. He also holds two master's degrees: [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in [[Information Science|Information]] and [[Computer Science]] from the [[University of California, Irvine]] (1999) and [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in Health Care Administration from the [[California State University, Long Beach]] (1995). He received his [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in [[Biological Science]]s from the [[University of California, Irvine]] (1994) and [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[Political Science]] from the [[University of California, Irvine]] (1992).
==Research== Dr. Reddy's research interests are [[Medical Informatics]], [[Computer-supported collaboration|Computer-Supported Cooperative Work]], [[Human-Computer Interaction]], and [[Information Science]]s. He has published ten papers on [[academic journal]]s or books, and eleven papers on [[peer-review]]ed conference proceedings (till October 2007).
His previous research focused on examining how patient care team members used their knowledge of temporal features of work (e.g., temporal rhythms, trajectories, and horizons) for collaborative purposes. The research provided a theoretical basis for understanding the centrality of temporality in collaborative work and highlighted the importance of incorporating temporal features into the design of information systems.
Most of his current research focuses on three major themes: (1) Collaborative information behavior; (2) Temporal features of collaborative work and (3) Collaborative support for teams. He explores these themes utilizing qualitative methods within the [[health care]] domain primarily in hospital environments.
His research collaborators include [[Paul Dourish]], [[Wanda Pratt]], John King, [[Mark Ackerman]], [[Jonathan Grudin]], [[Gloria Mark]], [[John Yen]], etc.
==See also== * [[Medical Informatics]] * [[Information Science]] * [[Computer-supported collaboration|Computer-Supported Cooperative Work]] * [[Human-Computer Interaction]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://faculty.ist.psu.edu/reddy/ Madhu Reddy's homepage] * [http://ist.psu.edu Penn State College of Information Sciences and Technology (IST)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071013142124/http://ist.psu.edu/ist/directory/faculty/?EmployeeID=379 Introduction to Madhu Reddy at Penn State IST website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reddy, Madhu}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Health informaticians]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University faculty]] [[Category:California State University, Long Beach alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Irvine alumni]] [[Category:Missouri University of Science and Technology faculty]]

'''Marian Chace''' (31 October 1896 – 19 July 1970) is one of the founders of modern [[dance therapy]].
Marion Chace was born 31 October 1896 in [[Providence, Rhode Island]], the daughter of Daniel Champlin Chace, a journalist and editor, and Harriet Edgaretta (Northrop) Chace. Her younger siblings were Marjorie (1899–1991), Olive (1905–1977), and Edgar Northrop Chace (1908–1983).
She studied modern [[dance]] and [[choreography]] with [[Ted Shawn]] and [[Ruth St. Denis]] at the [[Denishawn]] School of Dance and started work as a dance performer. However she believed that the body and mind are interrelated, and influenced by the work of [[Carl Jung]].
She began to teach in Washington D.C. and noticed some of her students were more interested in the expression of emotions than in dance technique and began to emphasize this in her classes. Her students reported feelings of well being which intrigued local doctors, some of the National Institutes of Health, who began to send some of their patients to her classes. Her approach included body active, symbolism, therapeutic movement relationship, and rhythmic group activity. Eventually she joined the staff at St. Elizabeth’s hospital in southeast Washington D.C. and studied at the Washington School of Psychiatry. Chace started to teach in schools and hospitals advocating and lecturing on the therapeutic benefits of dance/body movement. <ref> Marian Chace Biography www.adta.org/Marian_Chace_Biography.</ref> She worked for a number of years with patients at [[Chestnut Lodge]] in Rockville, MD.
In the 1960s she founded a training program for dance therapists New York. In 1966 she founded the [[American Dance Therapy Association]] and became its first president.
==References== <references />> "Marian Chace: Her Papers" by Harris Chaiklin. Columbia, Maryland:American Dance Therapy Association, 1975.
healthpronet.org/ahp_month/04_05.html

{{Other uses|Saint Mary's Hospital (disambiguation)}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Mount St. Mary's Hospital and Health Center''' is a privately sponsored [[Catholic]] [[hospital]] in [[Lewiston, New York]], just north of [[Niagara Falls, New York]], where approximately 60% of the hospital's patients reside.
The hospital was formed in 1907 by the [[Sisters of St. Francis of Assisi|Sisters of St. Francis]], who came north from [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] to care for the sick and the poor. In 1997, the Sisters of St. Francis turned over sponsorship to the Daughters of Charity. In 2000, the [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul|Daughters of Charity]] merged with the Sisters of St. Joseph to create [[Ascension Health]]. The system expanded in 2002 with the addition of the [[Sisters of St. Joseph]] of Carondelet Health System. Ascension Health is the largest not-for-profit and religiously sponsored healthcare system in the nation.
Mount St. Mary's includes: * 175-bed licensed acute care facility * Full service 24/7 EmStar Emergency Department * Clearview inpatient chemical dependency unit * 250-bed skilled care and rehabilitation center, Our Lady of Peace Nursing Care Residence * Center for Women OB/GYN Maternity unit * Primary care clinic located in the inner city of the City of Niagara Falls * Primary care clinic located on the hospital's Lewiston campus * Child care center * Charitable foundation In 2012 the hospital had an annual payroll and benefits of more than $54 million.
Staff includes nearly 200 physicians, more than 300 RNs and LPNs, and allied health professionals and numerous employees in supporting roles. In all, Mount St. Mary’s Hospital and Health Center employs more than 1,200 people and has about 250 volunteers. Mount St. Mary's is a New York State Department of Health Designated Stroke Center and a certified Chest Pain Center. It is also the only hospital in the Niagara area accredited by The Joint Commission.
{{Ascension Health}}
{{coord missing|New York (state)}}
[[Category:Hospitals in New York (state)]] [[Category:Hospitals affiliated with the Catholic Church]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2017}} The '''Museum of Pasta''' (in [[Italian language|Italian]] '''Museo della pasta''') is an Italian [[ethnography|ethnographic]] [[museum]] dedicated to [[pasta]]. It is located in [[Corte di Giarola]], between [[Collecchio]] and Ozzano Taro, in the [[Province of Parma]], a region historically dedicated to the production and processing of pasta. The museum shares space with the [[Museum of Tomato]] (in [[Italian language|Italian]] Museo del pomodoro).
==History== In 2001, the Comitato Promotore dei Musei del Cibo (literally the Promoting Committee of Food Museums) was founded. Starting 2003 and 2004, it cooperated with the Association of the Food Museums of the Province of Parma, that had brought together the Province of Parma, the Communes of [[Soragna]], [[Langhirano]] and [[Collecchio]], a consortium of protectionists of typical food products, the Chamber of Commerce of Parma and various economic associations, all interested in the creation and management of a network of Food Museums in the province of Parma. This resulted in launching of an initiative to establish a museum in Corte di Giarola, a public building, and a great medieval rural court, as a museum dedicated to the tomato. It shares space with an adjoining Museum of Tomato (in [[Italian language|Italian]] Museo del pomodoro).
==Opening== The Museum of Pasta is located on the ground floor of the west wing of Corte di Giarola that was renovated. It was earlier a centre for processing agricultural food products dating back to the medieval times until the end of the 19th century, later a processing industry for conserve and food in for the first six decades of the 20th century.<ref>[http://turismo.comune.parma.it/en/thematic-channels/flavors/food-and-wine-factories/museum-of-tomato?set_language=en Services of the Museum of Food on Turismo Comune Parma website]</ref> The museum was inaugurated on May 10, 2014 coinciding with a conference with a convention dedicated to "La pasta tra storia, cultura e gastronomia" (meaning "Pasta: history, culture and gastronomy") with invitees collector Ettore Guatelli, poet Attilio Bertolucci and entrepreneur Pietro Barilla, the Italian coordinator of the Food Museums and famous food journalist Davide Paolini.
==Exhibits== The exhibition halls of the Museum of Pasta are divided into six sections. The first section, describes through a series of panels and documents, models and vintage farming tools and the historical evolution of grain and cereal cultivation techniques.The second hall illustrates, through panels, models, and the reconstruction of a mill the historical evolution of grinding techniques and the third hall bread and bakery products. The fourth hall illustrates, through a collection of small household utensils of the past, homemade pasta preparation techniques and various sizes of pasta. The fifth hall has a replica of an industrial pasta factory dating back to the early 19th century and some ancient machinery, the techniques of industrial pasta manufacturing and the methods of forming its more than hundred types. Finally the sixth hall illustrates, through panels, postcards, advertising leaflets, objects, paintings, stamps and catalogs, the rich culture of pasta in Italy.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.museidelcibo.it/page.asp?IDCategoria=225&IDSezione=0&ID=561012 Museum pf Pasta page] on [http://www.museidelcibo.it Musei del Cibo website]
